sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with non-square matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using the Gaussian elimination method:
$$\begin{cases} 2x + 3y - 5z = -1 \\ 3y + z = -4 \\ 6x + 5y - 3z = 7 \end{cases}$$
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using the Gaussian elimination method, we first write the augmented matrix:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & 3 & -5 & -1 \\ 0 & 3 & 1 & -4 \\ 6 & 5 & -3 & 7 \end{array}\right]$$

Now, we perform row operations to get the matrix in row-echelon form. We start by eliminating the 6 in the third row, first row:

$$R_3 = R_3 - 3R_1$$

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & 3 & -5 & -1 \\ 0 & 3 & 1 & -4 \\ 0 & -4 & 12 & 10 \end{array}\right]$$

Next, we eliminate the -4 in the third row, second column:

$$R_3 = R_3 + \frac{4}{3}R_2$$

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & 3 & -5 & -1 \\ 0 & 3 & 1 & -4 \\ 0 & 0 & 14 & 2 \end{array}\right]$$

Now, we have the matrix in row-echelon form. We can now perform back-substitution to find the solutions for x, y, and z.

First, we find z:

$$14z = 2 \Rightarrow z = \frac{1}{7}$$

Next, we find y:

$$3y + 1\left(\frac{1}{7}\right) = -4 \Rightarrow y = -\frac{41}{21}$$

Finally, we find x:

$$2x + 3\left(-\frac{41}{21}\right) - 5\left(\frac{1}{7}\right) = -1 \Rightarrow x = \frac{23}{14}$$

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is:

$$x = \frac{23}{14}, y = -\frac{41}{21}, z = \frac{1}{7}$$
